question: What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.

comments.comment: I would get rid of the tipping system entirely.  Too many places that shouldn't be asking for tips are and people are being bullied into it.

Tipping should be based on quality of service provided, but I think the tipping culture for every small transaction is an overkill. What used to be a basic transaction, now I can't pay for things without the tipping menu popup.
If I were to improve the tipping system I would possibly make it so the customer receives something for the tip. For example, a written thank you note. A coupon could also be given for the next time.

I always tip at every establishment I go to. Regarding the tipping system, I am not sure what I would change about the tipping system, but I would change that everyone gets a base hourly wage that is livable, because a lot of workers who get tips have very low hourly wages and they rely heavily on tips and sometimes people just don't tip.
I think that tipping is okay as long as you are not pressured into it. I think businesses should be required to pay people a livable wage so that they don't have to rely on tips.
I would get rid of mandatory tipping and make the employee pay there employees a decent living wge. The responsibility is on them
i think most restaurants should make the system free and not manadatory. Customers dont have to be forced to pay mandatory tips

Tipping is beneficial for the one who is receiving. However most people don’t follow the tipping system. Based on the professional service or polite attitude the may may turn out to be more then the tipping system. On the other hand you may want to tip big and you really just don’t have it financially to do so, in return you tip what you can to assure you let your server know you appreciated them.
I think tipping is fine when its to just add something extra for good service. I dont think tipping should be forced or implied for 0 service or very minimal.

I would probably change the usual way of thinking about tipping from percentages to fixed amounts, and I'd also have people tip more because I just feel like what people actually tip is barely anything (when the bill is low, anyway), and so basically I'd make, say, the $20 or $30 tip the standard amount and then that would be that.
Tipping has become over-expected in the United States.  I really do not like being asked for tips in many cases, like when I pick up my own pizza.

In America at least it's borderline mandatory for servers and other members of the service sector due to not being paid a living wage. Ideally I wouldn't tip or it would be factored in the bill but because it is the way it is I always tip at restaurants/bars or when I order food delivery. I would improve it by having people who work those jobs be paid a living wage.
I sadly don’t enjoy tipping. I used to work in a field where tipping was 80% of my pay. We should take note on the way Europe does it. Pay more so tipping isn’t necessary.
I don't have an issue with it but people who don't provide good service and expect a tip are in the wrong in my opinion
I think it's out of control in the US. It's a way for employers to get away with paying their employees less and it's gotta stop.
i would ensure the tipping wage has a standard for every level of purchase , this would ensure that customers are not manipulated to give more than they can afford
Only the United States has this kind of system. It would be better if we inte tips into the payment.
It is not necessary, but I believe people should be compelled to do it. Most workers do not earn enough, and tipping can help address this issue.

I strongly oppose the tipping system. I would change the current tipping system by replacing it with a compulsory 10% service charge for all restaurants. Tipping would be optional and should not appear on the bill.

My opinion is that it seems a bit forced in certain societies. If I could change the tipping system, at least where I'm at in the West, I would probably only encourage tipping as something one does out of gratitude.

My opinion is that tipped workers should be paid minimum wage so that they don't have to rely on tips anymore. The reason I say that is because tipping has become too expensive for consumers, so it should be made more optional and less expensive.
I don't think that tipping should exist.  Waiters should be paid a fair wage.

Tipping is getting out of hand due to the tablet point of sale systems. Places that used to not have tipping now are asking for tips, and it's uncomfortable to say no or requires multiple taps to get to 0%. By default, the point of sale systems should have an easy to find "no tip" option on the initial screen. It also would be better if tips were not requested unless a clear service (preparing food, serving, bussing tables, etc) is provided.
it should be adopted by everyone as it is a good deed to appreciate others for their skill

I hate tipping.  I believe a company should pay their employees a proper wage and so I do not feel obliged to tip. I would change the system by getting rid of it and tipping be something voluntary because they did a good job.

I think the current system is awful. You either feel obligated to tip bad service or pressured to tip before you even receive the service. No tip should be asked or entered until services rendered and the service is rated by the customer.

I will always tip if I go out to eat at a restaurant, but if I had to change the current tipping system, I would completely abolish it to begin with. It is completely unfair to the waiters and waitresses who should be getting fairly compensated without having to rely heavily on tips to get by.

I think servers deserve a tip that reflects their service to me or someone.  I have worked with students all my life and believe servers deserve to be compensated for their work.  I always overtip.  I think no taxes on tips is a great move.

I believe in tipping if the server has gone above and beyond to help me.  A lot of the jobs they do are hard, demanding activities.  I know myself I would appreciate a little extra in my pockets beside the standard wage.
I will give a good tip of the service is good. I will not give a good tip of the service is bad.
I agree with tipping. The system should be left up to the patron on how much to tip and it should be earned by the wait staff.
The current tipping system is mainly a way for employers to underpay employees and squeeze more profit. Tipping should be voluntary and for good service.

I would abolish forcing food service workers to try to make a living off of tips. Tipping should be an option, however, workers should be paid a living wage and patrons should not feel obligated to always tip.

I don't think there is anything wrong with the system itself but there is something wrong with tippers!  People shouldn't use services that involve tips if they have no money to tip.  Possibly making tips mandatory as part of the total bill may be a future option!

My opinion on tipping has become largely negatively in the past 5 years. It feels like every establishment nowadays has one of those tipping screens on their checkout register. I think tipping should only be a thing on sit-down restaurants where you get full service and not a fast food place. But even then, i think it should be optional and even then that's pushing it in my opinion. I think the minimum wage in the US should be raised across the board in order to one day end tipping culture.

I think tipping is great, if the service is good. I wish servers weren't paid so little for the work they do even if they get a lot of tips. I think tipping should mostly be reserved for the servers who have done the best job.

For workers it is great because they can potentially make more than minimum wage. For consumers it can be bad with everyone now wanting a tip for everything. I would honestly just get rid of tipping and paying servers a fair wage. This puts less stress on the consumer to figure out what is a good tip, and less stress on the worker wondering how much they will make.
Tipping is fine in restaurants but not when you're ordering coffee and just picking it up.

I think that it depends on the locality. Here in the USA, tipping is socially established as a norm. I would take away tipping alltogether. Frankly its better to move towards an automated system and take the human being outside of the realm of the Service/Manufacturing Industries.

I am tired of tipping culture, I understand that restaurant workers are severely underpaid but it feels like tipping culture is out of hand and a tip is expected for everything. I would raise the prices so that workers get paid more but tip would be eliminated. I would be fine with paying a higher price for my meal if I know that it is going to workers.

I 100% agree with tipping. I always tip at least 20% and I believe that it is a great incentive for employees to go above and beyond at their job. I also believe that tipping should be mandatory unless the company pays their employees a minimum wage of at least $15 and does not tax their tips.
Remove tipping and add a service charge of 10%. That's what they do in Japan and elsewhere and it makes it easier for everyone
I choose what to tip. I tip well for good service and I avoid businesses that try to tip for me.
I think some tipping systems should be less intrusive and be presented as optional, depending on the service provided.
Who should be tipped needs to be limited to those working in restaurants. The tipping system today is out of control.
I believe in tipping if the service is good.  The amount that I tip also depends on the service that I receive.  I don't believe in tipping for pickup orders or drive thru orders.
I am considered a very generous tipper, but it is getting outrageous with the people trying to get tipped now. They want tips when they aren't even serving you directly.

I think tipping is a necessary "evil" as long as waiters and other service people rely on them as their "wage."  I think it could be improved or changed by just making them receive a fair wage and not put the onus of tipping on the customer/consumer.

The tipping system in the US most vitally applies to food servers, who are paid a criminally paltry amount of $2.13 per hour, a fraction of the still impossibly low federal minimum wage of $7.25 per hour, so that tips are highly necessary for their survival. Tipping system doesn't necessarily need changing, but all workers should make at the very least the federal minimum wage. Minimum wage has not changed since 2009 and needs to be livable, i.e. at least $15 / hour.
In general, I think tipping has become far too expected. I wish we could go back to when tipping was infrequent and appreciated. Nowadays it seems everyone wants a tip, and a high tip at that.

i would only think its ok to ask  for a tip for a complex order not for something basic like a shot of espresso or buying a bottle of water at starbucks. i have a strong dislike for the tipping culture.

While I always make sure to leave generous tips, I also have a deep dislike for tipping culture. I think it would be better if businesses would pay their employees a living wage rather than leaving them to depend on tips.
Tipping is for a service provided. Not for just being at the business. When I make my own fountain drink and come to pay, and the cashier ask how much to tip, this is pathetic.

I think the current tipping system is horrible and confusing, as many establishments try to get you to tip before you even receive service (or if it's pickup, why are you even tipping?). Instead, there needs to be more pressure on businesses to pay their workers fairly and less reliance on the "tip" to justify poor business practices.
I think that tipping is a flat out scam. I believe that a person's employer should be solely responsible for paying them. I would change the system by completely getting rid of it.

Some people seem to tip to boost their egos and flaunt their wealth while other people probably feel bad because they can't tip much if at all since they're too poor. I would change the current tipping system by not treating employees like objects that need to be judged. People should be encouraged to tip if they genuinely want to do a good deed for employees.
I do not agree to have to tip every time you buy something. We should not be forced or asked to tip. They need to stop the forced tipping on screens etc.

i think it's a little bit out of hand in the sense that they want us to tip on everything. I understand tipping a server who is actually serving you, but not one who is only taking your order as part of their job. they are not doing anything extra to earn a tip. Here's a tip, pay your employees a living wage so they don't have to depend on tips.

I am conflicted. I want workers to be paid fairly and with a living wage, but I feel like their pay shouldn't rely solely on tipping culture. I wish they could get paid enough for necessities by their companies and businesses that they work for. However, with that being said, I try my best to tip people fairly.

I truly do not know enough about receiving tips to give an educated reply. However, I do comply with the standard at the time. Also, I will add more if the situation calls for it. As far as improving it is concerned...maybe have employers add one quarter of the amount of tip s to tips earned.
I would adopt the european system the does not extort money from the customer to make up for the low wage that the employer offers.

I think tipping has gone overboard and consumers are subsidizing wages that the companies should pay to these employees. I don't believe every thing should be tipped and tip should be earned and actual service should be provided. I also don't believe in tipping or tipping well in a mom and pop shops.
My opinion about tipping is that it is something that is not required. Many people have lost their way when it comes to tipping and believing that it’s mandatory
I would have businesses stop expecting tips or asking for them. Nowadays, it seems like it is mandatory to tip. It should be up to the consumer if they chose to tip or not.

I don’t mind tipping but if I’m ordering a donut or a cookie that’s already on the display. I’m not going to tip you for handing it to me. Companies need to pay their employees better so the tipping system isn’t so crazy like it is.
I wish tipping wasn't allowed. I feel like the businesses should just pay workers a fair wage.

I think the tipping system is very broken. The basis for people who do a service to receive an EXTRA amount of pay for doing an exceptional job is great. However that is not how it is implemented. In the food service industry especially, although in other service based businesses too, tipping has become a reason to NOT pay a reasonable living wage on the idea that their good service will make up the difference instead of the intended BONUS which is what a tip is supposed to be.

I prefer not to be asked for a tip or have a system suggest a tip for me.  I can determine if, when, and how much to tip without being prompted.  It feels like an imposition when a tip is asked for, particularly in instances where a tip doesn't seem appropriate to me.
I don't mind tipping.  However, I believe if restaurant workers were paid a living wage, tipping would not be necessary.

Tipping is cumbersome and unpredictable, as workers do not know how much money they are going to earn. This might be offset by a flat service fee that is charged on the bill so that the workers will not be overworked to the detriment of the customers.

Tipping should be given by the consumer to the server for excellent service . I personally will leave a very large,  generous tip when I am very happy with the service I have received , and if the service is not so good , my tip will be substantially lower. It is not the consumers responsibility to make up for low wages paid by an employer  . Tipping should always be optional .
I believe in tipping for good service. I don't understand tipping people at Subway and Dunkin Donuts. That is their job. I understand their wages aren't that. I have been in their situation.
I only believe tipping is well deserved if they provided excellent customer service. A lot of people who work horribly still expect a tip and I don't think people like that even deserve it.

I think tipping should be optional at all establishments because you never know when someone is feeling generous. However, I don't think that it needs to be the standard unless in a restaurant or receiving an actual service. Establishments that ask for a tip when they are simply packaging food is a bit silly.

I think tipping someone for good/great service is fine. If they do a good/great job, they should be tipped. We can improve tipping by making it based on the quality of service and not just tipping to tip.
I think that employers should pay a fair wage and that the tipping culture shouldn't exist anymore unless the service is spectacular. It's a dated system that needs to be abolished.

I wish tipping culture wasn't necessary so workers who earn them can have a steady, livable income. While we do have it, I think tipping is important because the people who serve us rely on that for their income since they usually have a low base pay. If it were up to me, the tipping system would end and businesses would be required to pay their workers fairly.

I believe tipping should not be required ever because it takes away the kindness people offer via tips. I worked for tips as a delivery driver and the hardest part was people thinking I expected a tip. Tips should not be required but should be given to those who deserve it.

I don't mind tipping servers or people who provide service. However, if i am just ordering at a counter or picking up I dont think a tip is needed. I think that the waitress base pay is appalling and they should be paid at the very minimum, federal minimum wage.
tipping is too confusing, everyone asks, but not everyone really needs extra beyond their wages.
I think tipping should only be required for servers and food delivery. Other than that you should be able to choose when and how much to tip
I dislike the current tipping system. I would prefer employers paying their employees fair wages and not rely on tips. I would rather not tip at all.
I think its an unfortunate necessity. Workers deserve to be paid a fair wage. I would make it so that workers earn a livable wage so that tipping isn't essentially a requirement.
I believe in tipping when I seek a service out like food delivery or restaurant service. I would improve the current tipping system by reducing the automated suggested tip amount percentage.

I feel like for services like ordering coffee or ordering something to go, we shouldn't be expected to tip. I would want these types of service workers to be paid at least minimum wage so that they don't have to rely on tips or if we do tip, just leave a tip jar but make it optional.
Tipping is fine I would say I do it often and is not a bother to me. I would not change anything because the tipping really does help the workers.
I would make sure that servers do not have to rely on tips the most. Everyone deserves to make money to live.

I think that swinging around the iPad and automatically expecting people to tip for counter service is frustrating. I have no problem tipping people who bring me food or wait on me. I think that places where people are paid a living wage should not have the iPad tipping system. Or they should at least make it clear that it is not expected. If they want a tip, it should be baked into the price.
The service industry is hard work, and quality service can make or break an outing.  I fully support tipping, and believe 25% to 30% is appropriate.
I think tipping is wonderful and a great way to give back to others. However, I feel that over the counter, direct service should necessarily be tipped.

I think the current tipping system is flawed. If given the opportunity I would first make sure that workers properly got paid instead of relying on tips. We need to hold companies more accountable to pay a living wage rather than rely on tipping.
i tip if i go to a sit down eating place but i dont believe in tipping in fast food places where you get the food yourself
I think tipping is a must and it's very generous of that person to give a tip. The employees don't sometimes make enough at their jobs and you tipping them is really helping those out.
I dislike tipping. Employers should pay employees fairly.
I believe that you should only tip if there is good service. If there is no good service or if it was not a nice interaction then people have the right to not tip at all.

I think tipping should only be for exceptional service rather than any service. I would implement a law where tipping is only available for sit down services. Furthermore I would cap the tip percentage on the low end to start at 15% no more.
